# Background

Your Cuban uncle sets up a cocktail bar in downtown Budapest. He has a secret list of cocktails that he would like to serve in the bar. He asks you to do create a few lists and tables to set up the shop. As your uncle is a secret hipster, he has a dataset on Github that you can use for the task!

## 1. Read the data

Read the cocktail dataset from: <https://github.com/nthun/cocktail-balance> You can also find the codebook there.

```{r}
library(tidyverse)
library(readr)

cocktails <- read_tsv("https://raw.githubusercontent.com/nthun/cocktail-balance/master/cocktail_data.tsv")
```

## 2. Transform the data table and clean the ingredient variable!

The ingredients are currently in a single cell for each cocktail. It would be better to put them in separate rows. Also, the variable should be cleaned of all quantities (e.g. 1/2 oz, 2 dashes, etc.), and the indicator of alcohol content (e.g. 47.3% abv). You will need to use this cleaned table in later tasks.

```{r}
library(dplyr)
library(stringr)
library(tidyr)

cocktails_clean <- cocktails %>%
  mutate(ingredients = as.character(ingredients)) %>%

  # Removing HTML tags
  mutate(ingredients = str_replace_all(ingredients, "<br\\s*/?>", ","),
         ingredients = str_replace_all(ingredients, "<[^>]+>", ",")) %>%

  # Cleaning Unicode and non-ASCII characters 
  mutate(
    ingredients = str_replace_all(ingredients, "\\\\u[0-9a-fA-F]{4}", " "),
    ingredients = str_replace_all(ingredients, "[^\\x00-\\x7F]", " ")
  ) %>%

  # Removal of fractions (1/2, 3/4, etc.)
  mutate(ingredients = str_replace_all(ingredients, "\\b\\d+\\s*/\\s*\\d+\\b", " ")) %>%

  # Standardization of bad separators 
  mutate(ingredients = str_replace_all(ingredients, "[/\\\\]+", ",")) %>%

  # Removal of lonely numbers 
  mutate(ingredients = str_replace_all(ingredients,
                                       "(^|,|\\n)\\s*\\.?\\s*\\d+\\s*\\.?\\s*(,|$)",
                                       ",")) %>%

  # Removal of quantities, alcohol % and parentheses
  mutate(
    ingredients = str_remove_all(ingredients, "\\([^\\)]*\\)"),       # ( ... )
    ingredients = str_remove_all(ingredients, "[0-9]+\\.?[0-9]*%\\s*abv"),  # 47% abv
    ingredients = str_remove_all(
      ingredients,
      "\\b\\d+\\s*(oz|ml|cl|tsp|tbsp|bsp|cup|part|dash(?:es)?|barspoon|drop(?:s)?)s?\\b"
    ),
    ingredients = str_remove_all(ingredients, "\\b\\d+\\b")
  ) %>%

  # Break into multiple lines
  separate_rows(ingredients, sep = "[,\\n;]") %>%

  # Cleaning whitespace
  mutate(
    ingredients = str_squish(ingredients),
    ingredients = str_trim(ingredients),
    ingredients = str_to_lower(ingredients)
  ) %>%

  # Filtering out junk lines 
  filter(
    ingredients != "",
    !str_detect(ingredients, "^[\\d\\.\\s]+$"),
    nchar(ingredients) > 1,
    !str_detect(ingredients, "^\\W+$")
  ) %>%

  # Some common fixes
  mutate(ingredients = str_replace_all(ingredients, "^lemon\\s*juice$", "lemon juice"),
         ingredients = str_replace_all(ingredients, "^lime\\s*juice$", "lime juice")) %>%

  distinct(name, ingredients, .keep_all = TRUE) %>%

  # Second Cleaning round
  mutate(ingredients = str_replace_all(ingredients, "(^|,)\\s*\\d+\\s*\\.\\s*", ",")) %>%
  mutate(ingredients = str_squish(ingredients)) %>%
  mutate(
    ingredients = str_remove(ingredients, "^\\d+\\s*"),
    ingredients = str_remove(ingredients, "^\\.*\\s*")
  ) %>%

  # Further uniform quantity removal
  mutate(
    ingredients = str_remove_all(
      ingredients,
      "\\b(oz|ml|cl|tsp|tbsp|bsp|cup|part|dash(?:es)?|barspoon|drop(?:s)?)\\b"
    ),
    ingredients = str_squish(ingredients)
  ) %>%
  filter(ingredients != "") %>%

  # Final cleaning
  mutate(
    ingredients = str_remove_all(
      ingredients,
      "\\boz\\b|\\bml\\b|\\bcl\\b|\\btsp\\b|\\btbsp\\b|\\bbsp\\b|\\bcup\\b|\\bpart\\b|\\bdash(?:es)?\\b|\\bbarspoon\\b|\\bdrops?\\b"
    ),
    ingredients = str_squish(ingredients),
    ingredients = str_trim(ingredients)
  ) %>%
  filter(ingredients != "")

library(dplyr)
library(stringr)

# Redefinition of necessary variables
units_pattern <- "oz|ml|cl|tsp|tbsp|bsp|cup|part|dash|dashes|barspoon|drop|drops"

problems <- list(
  numbers   = cocktails_clean %>% filter(str_detect(ingredients, "\\d")),
  units     = cocktails_clean %>% filter(str_detect(ingredients, units_pattern)),
  html      = cocktails_clean %>% filter(str_detect(ingredients, "<[^>]+>")),
  non_ascii = cocktails_clean %>% filter(str_detect(ingredients, "[^\\x00-\\x7F]")),
  symbols   = cocktails_clean %>% filter(str_detect(ingredients, "^\\W+$")),
  empty     = cocktails_clean %>% filter(ingredients == "" | is.na(ingredients)),
  short     = cocktails_clean %>% filter(nchar(ingredients) < 2)
)

lapply(problems, function(x) nrow(x))
```

## 3. All ingredients in alphabetical order

Before opening the bar, you need to find a reliable supplier that has all the ingredients. You need to send a list of all possible ingredients you will need. They don't need the quantities (i.e. how many of these are needed), just the names of the ingredients.

```{r}
# 3. All ingredients in alphabetical order
ingredients_list <- cocktails_clean %>%
  distinct(ingredients) %>%    
  arrange(ingredients)  
View(ingredients_list)
```

## 10. Create a cheat sheet for the bartender!

Create a matrix that shows all cocktail names as rows and all ingredients as columns. When a cocktail requires an ingredient, there should be an "X" in the cell, otherwise, the cell should remain empty. Example:

```{r echo=FALSE}
tribble(~name, ~Lime, ~`White rum`, ~`Cane sugar`, ~`Coca-cola`, ~Mint, ~Soda,
        "Caipirissima", "X", "X", "X", "", "", "",
        "Cuba Libre", "X", "X", "", "X","","",
        "Mojito", "X", "X", "", "", "X", "X") %>% 
    relocate(name, sort(names(.)))
```
